{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3325202,"name":"Mehir","username":"AKD","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/e99b99/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-06T01:18:56.135Z","cooked":"

I keep getting a command scheduler overrun even though I’m running one command. The problem occurred originally when we had the full robot code running. This caused the robot to pause sometimes and run all the controller movements together on the drive. I’ve seen in other forums that the buttons.run() warning means that there’s something wrong will how you’re triggering commands with a button. All I have right now is a simple command binded to the y button which I’m triggering onTrue.I’ve tried changing commands to ones with different subsystems with no avail.

When asking for programming help, please try to share your code. Ideally as a link to github. Without it, we can only guess at what you’re doing.

I think the issue arises from using a color sensor plugged into i2c which was locking the system. From what I’ve seen the overrun warning is normal. After switching the port of the color sensor, we no longer have the issue of the robot becoming dead. I will make sure to post the code next time tho thank you for your help

No part of your OP is describing symptoms of the i2c lockup issue. Once that happens, you generally need to restart the Rio to get it back, so it shouldn’t present as a “pause” or anything.

In any case, yes, wiring devices (i.e. REV Color Sensor) to the Rio i2c port is generally a bad idea due to this issue. I’m assuming you rewired it to i2c pins on the Rio MXP port instead? You should know that port has also had problems reported, though significantly less frequently.

In any case, I’m glad that you’re back to a working state.

We had this issue today. After searching on CD we found a post discussing issues with the “whiletue/whilefalse” for button bindings.

Check out this thread for useful details.

Command Scheduler Loop Overrun Programming
A .zip of some of tonights Driver Station log files can be found on drive. Our code is hosted on github as MusicalToaster. Each subsystem has a thread (the camera class does have a thread, but is not a subsystem any more. This approach is similar to what CTRE did with their SwerveDrivetrain class. It became an issue when we were using Phoenix Tuner to run the right shooter motor so we could develop a table for determining good angles at different distances for our turret. It would run for may…
